channel.title: INfinance
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from INfinance, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: China Needs More Factory Robots. Can It Build Its Own?
item.description: Local production of industrial robots is rising, but Japanese and European makers still have a role.

item.title: The market is getting less efficient. Ape this strategy from meme-stock investors, veteran fund manager says
item.description: Don’t despair, but ape this strategy from meme-stock investors, says Clifford Asness.

item.title: Americans Are Really, Really Bullish on Stocks
item.description: Individuals are taking a peek at their 401(k)s and rejoicing.

item.title: Pfizer and Valneva report positive results in mid-stage trial of Lyme disease vaccine
item.description: The Phase 2 trial was evaluating the vaccine called VLA15 following a second booster dose given one year after the first one.

item.title: Japan Bank Shares Rise as 10-Year JGB Yield Hits Nearly One-Month High
item.description: Japanese bank stocks rose as the yield on the 10-year Japanese government bonds touched near a one-month high.

item.title: Before the Fed lowers interest rates, make these 4 money moves to prepare your finances
item.description: With Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell saying “the time has come” for rate cuts, here’s how to handle credit-card debt, cash and big purchases.

item.title: Stock Futures Are Little Changed as Investors Await Jobs Report Later This Week
item.description: U.S. stock and bond markets were closed for Labor Day. Germany’s DAX index closed at a record high.

item.title: We’re in our 60s and plan to claim Social Security at 70. Does delaying for maximum benefits really make sense?
item.description: “I am planning to apply for Social Security at 70 to get the higher benefits.”

item.title: Markets' Summer Vacation Is Over
item.description: These charts show the tests ahead for stocks, bonds and energy.

item.title: 5 market sectors and 9 stocks to keep on your radar in September
item.description: September is the market’s cruelest month — except in presidential election years.
